The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is a significant advance over previous attempts to provide a categorical foundation for quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which includes a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, that is similar to the stinging structures in cnidarians, has been elusive. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals and that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by extreme reduction in gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this pandemic, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has been shown to evade the antiviral action of interferon (IFN) by blocking nuclear import of transcription factors that are essential for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of transcription factors. We show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the mechanism of action of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in dietary samples. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses between March 28 and April 4, 2020. The survey asked about the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on business operations and financial health. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, the majority of businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected. This is mainly due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the ocean. The fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is still a matter of debate. Some authors suggest that SiC grains are presolar, i.e., they formed in the interiors of stars. However, the origin of the majority of SiC grains is still unknown. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that the majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. A minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. Our results provide evidence that the majority of SiC grains are presolar. This conclusion is supported by the fact that SiC grains are found in carbonaceous chondrites, which are considered to be the building blocks of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded dramatically. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to produce offspring is a fundamental characteristic of all animals. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work provides insight into the evolution of mammalian reproductive output and the evolution of domestication. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of allonursing in humans. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis. In response, many public health agencies and researchers have needed to track the pandemic and its effects. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are available for use in research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the regulation of neuronal excitability, and the transmission of nerve impulses. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The selectivity filter is formed by the interaction of the transmembrane segments with the loop connecting them. The selectivity filter is closed in the inactive state and opens upon channel activation. In this study, we show that the selectivity filter can be collapsed by the structural collapse of the activation gate. This finding provides a mechanism for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation in the K+ channel family. Finally, it provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation in the K+ channel family.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The composition of the gut microbiome is influenced by the host, the diet, and the gut microbiota itself. The gut microbiome is also dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change over time. The gut microbiome is also important for the health of the host, and the composition of the microbiome can influence the health of the host. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is known to influence social behavior, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens in the development of a subordinate status. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases that can precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized and effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The structures are also heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. It is expressed in two forms, fetal hemoglobin and adult hemoglobin. The expression of fetal hemoglobin is developmentally regulated and is important for the survival of the fetus. The expression of adult hemoglobin is regulated by the transcription factor BCL11A. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway and that it mediates the developmental silencing of BCL11A. This mechanism may be important for the regulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Conversely, ectopic expression of SREPB1 or SCD1 restored ferroptosis resistance in these cells, even when mTORC1 was inhibited.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds. However, it did halt clearcutting on federal land, which has been critical for the conservation of older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management, which are central to the NWFP. This study provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the pharmaceutical industry. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We screened a library of 1,000 compounds and identified 10 candidates that were tested in vitro and in vivo. The best candidate is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used acylide antibiotic. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. The approach presented here can be used to develop new antibiotics against other classes of antibiotics. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the impact of such devices on sleep has not been well studied. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is the most enigmatic event in the last glacial period. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust (= 1.3), indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. In contrast, bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania exhibit 187Os/188Os ratios <<1.0 and at face value suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os. However, the Os concentration in bulk sample and magnetic grains from Belgium is 2.8 pg/g and 15 pg/g, respectively, much lower than that in average upper continental crust (=31 pg/g), indicating no meteoritic contribution. CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 deletion induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but led to the development of autoantibodies against organ-specific antigens. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells, but this was not sufficient to prevent the development of autoimmunity. Moreover, CTLA-4 deletion had opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4 deficiency affected both central and peripheral tolerance, it was essential for the development of autoimmunity. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and traced the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that beetle diversity resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant-digesting enzymes. This study thus provides a new perspective on the evolution of beetles and their symbionts. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the risk of variants escaping neutralizing antibodies and may contribute to the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele. APOE is a major protein of the blood-brain barrier and is produced by astrocytes, a major cell type of the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of a protein that is a marker of senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate AD pathogenesis by accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE4 is associated with a higher risk of AD and that APOE4 is associated with a lower rate of accumulation of the protein that is a marker of senescent synapses. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a target for the development of new therapies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the planet, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3. The inner core is hypothesized to have formed by the solidification of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase, which is the stable phase at the inner core temperature. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase, which is the stable phase at the outer core temperature. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It also provides a clue to understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to have negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to dopamine may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human skill. It is also the most complex and important cognitive ability in modern society. Despite its importance, we still do not understand how the human brain processes language. Here, we use a state-of-the-art machine learning approach to show that the most powerful models in this domain are also the most accurate at predicting the brain responses to language in humans. This suggests that the brain is processing language in a similar way to the most powerful models. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the brain. They also suggest that we may be able to use machine learning models to understand the brain. This could lead to new insights into the brain and new computational tools for neuroscience.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to find a stable solution to the problem or due to its black-box nature. We study this question by introducing a new theory of stability for neural networks. We prove that there are problems for which there is no algorithm that can find a stable solution to the problem. This implies that the success of DL is not due to its ability to find stable solutions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a major focus of public attention. In this context, the role of people’s inability to understand exponential growth has been emphasized. This is based on a classic experiment published 45 years ago. However, its critical design flaws have been overlooked. Here, we discuss these flaws and their consequences for the interpretation of the study.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, which harbors a near-complete genome of an uncultured leprosy bacillus. We compared the genome of this new species with that of Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We found that the two species have retained many of the same functions, despite their ancient separation. This suggests that the two species are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study also provides a phylogeographic survey of leprosy, which reveals that the new species is restricted to Mexico. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the laws of thermodynamics, respectively. Therefore, understanding the evolution of entanglement is crucial for understanding the laws of nature. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics, as it allows for a complete description of the entanglement evolution in the space–time scaling limit.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only currently available vaccine against COVID-19 is the messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine, which requires cold storage and is not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is easy to manufacture and store at room temperature. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature, which is a major advantage over the currently available mRNA vaccines. In addition, the vaccine is codon optimized, which increases the expression of the spike protein and, therefore, the antibody response. The vaccine is also easy to manufacture in large quantities, which is a major advantage for mass vaccination programs. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been the subject of many studies, but the history of plague in Europe is poorly understood. In this study, we use a mathematical model to investigate the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). We find that human ectoparasites were the primary vectors of plague during this period, challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results have important implications for the control of plague, as well as for the study of the history of disease in Europe. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the ability to process information, has been neglected. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is not only different from that of brain size but also has a different evolutionary trajectory. The evolution of brain power is characterized by four major shifts in the number of neurons. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. The other two major increases happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. The disassembly process is controlled by the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. These proteins are the central regulators of actin filament disassembly. Here, we study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior are not well understood. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite and may promote feeding behavior. Our results have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior and for developing strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is revealed by the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island. The results suggest that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several independent waves, with a sex bias in the contribution of African and Asian ancestry. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It is also a reminder that the history of Madagascar is not only the history of the Malagasy people but also the history of Madagascar. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Emotional contagion is the process by which people experience the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the evidence for it in the real world is controversial. In this work, we test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed. We find that when positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription. One of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), is found in coding regions of mRNA. We show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain and the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu. We also find that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the bacterial translation system. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ can alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust over a 4-y period and are not explained by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a major theme in the history of life. We use a combination of comparative analysis and the fossil record to test hypotheses for the drivers of this pattern. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The virus responsible, rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. This study shows that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study also demonstrates that the innate immune response to rhinovirus is more robust at body temperature. These findings may help to explain the increased susceptibility to the common cold during the winter months and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of the common cold. Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like system that regulates the production of cAMP and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility and as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. Understanding the evolution of this mechanosensory system may provide new strategies for controlling bacterial pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the impact of pesticides on the quality of surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is responsible for millions of deaths. The virus has been documented in many animal species, but the extent to which these animals act as reservoirs for human disease is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. We also show that the virus has spread between deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. The hydropower industry is moving to build large dams in the developing world. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species, which are the most toxic forms of amyloid, are the primary drivers of an early inflammatory response in neurons. This response is not observed in neighboring glial cells, suggesting that neurons are uniquely vulnerable to the toxic effects of Aβ. We propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the proinflammatory factors that trigger the recruitment of microglia and the subsequent development of AD-related pathologies. Thus, we identify a previously unrecognized role for Aβ in the pathogenesis of AD. This study may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies to prevent or treat AD. (PsycInfo Database Record

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. In this paper, we study the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, by following the folding process at high structural resolution. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistage process.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, which is inactivated by stress conditions that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that, in the presence of stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decape Np4-capped RNAs, takes over the role of ApaH in removing the cap. We show that RppH prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs over their capped counterparts, and that the cap is removed by a mechanism distinct from the one used to remove other 5′ termini. This study reveals a mechanism for the preferential decapping of Np4-capped RNAs and provides a mechanistic explanation for the differential impact of Np4 on the rates at which capped and Np4-capped RNAs are degraded. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We have demonstrated that arginine, a key amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and regulatory T cells (Treg). We have also shown that arginine supplementation is able to restore T cell function and proliferation and to reduce the expansion of MDSCs and Treg. These results suggest that arginine supplementation could be a promising strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is the main component of the global carbon cycle. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics. It is characterized by the fact that the system is in a critical state and that the system’s dynamics are self-organized. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying strain. This opens up opportunities to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula. This peptide is highly dynamic and has a unique structure with one four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The antifungal activity of this peptide was also demonstrated. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides and opens up the possibility of developing this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the Drosophila sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα). Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of VWD mutations, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the low-force pathways are in the bulk phase. This is the first demonstration of a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. It is also the first demonstration of a mechanism for activating a protein that binds to platelets. This mechanism may be relevant to other proteins that bind to platelets. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been largely ignored. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome, and provides a comprehensive resource for the study of human-associated viruses. The study also provides a resource for the study of virus–disease associations, which are a major focus of the field.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. High-resolution and simultaneous observations of diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties are challenging for current remote-sensing techniques. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. These observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface is in turn controlled by the temperature of the atmosphere. Thus, the temperature of the atmosphere is a key factor in the evolution of life. The temperature of the atmosphere, in turn, is controlled by the composition of the atmosphere. Thus, the composition of the atmosphere is a key factor in the evolution of life. This paper demonstrates that the composition of the atmosphere is controlled by the temperature of the surface.

Potassium channels are important for the normal function of the heart, brain, and kidney. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks an intracellular activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may help us understand the BK channel’s normal function and may provide a basis for the development of BK channel blockers. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event, and the mechanisms by which the parasite enters the host cell are not fully understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, which may facilitate invasion. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection and disease severity. Our study may also be relevant to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in low humidity conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does so, however, remains unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how the brain builds syntactic structures. We found that the brain’s response to each successive word in a sentence increased with the complexity of the structure that word contributed to, suggesting that the brain applies a merge operation to each word. More complex structures were associated with more complex brain responses. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a protein that can be degraded by the proteasome. In the canonical Wnt pathway, Axin acts as a scaffold, which converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. This effect is blocked by dopamine antagonists, and dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) project to LH neurons. We show that this circuit is critical for the rapid eating induced by LH stimulation. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, this circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth and productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen to the plant, which is more efficient and environmentally sustainable than the use of synthetic nitrogen fertilizers. Here, we have developed a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen use in agriculture and to reduce the environmental impact of nitrogen-fixing symbioses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to incentivize deforestation monitoring by local communities. Despite the large number of such programs, the effectiveness of these programs is unknown. We study a program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are made of cells and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. We find that the spider’s web acts as an external ear, sensing the motion of the web in response to sound. The spider can adjust the size of the web to its needs and regenerate it after damage. This provides a unique system for studying the sensing and regeneration of external sensory organs.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C

COVID-19 vaccines are needed globally to contain the pandemic. Vaccine candidates based on recombinant proteins are well-established, proven interventions with multiple safe and efficacious commercial examples. Here we report an engineered sequence variant of the RBD, which mediates viral entry to cells via ACE2. This variant exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity after a single dose in mice compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD may be a useful component for a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern. This engineered RBD may also be useful for other applications, such as diagnostics and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is a heterogeneous group of tumors that arise from neural crest-derived tissues. In recent years, mutations in the ALK gene have been identified as a cause of several neuroblastoma subtypes. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALKALs are able to activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro and in vivo. Our results provide evidence that ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a molecular basis for the role of ALK/Ltk signaling in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This knowledge will be useful for the development of zebrafish models for neuroblastoma and for the identification of new therapeutic targets.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The study of ancient plague genomes has revealed the evolutionary steps that led to the emergence of plague as a distinct pathogen. However, the number of ancient plague genomes is too small to explore the diversity of the pathogen during its formative years. Here, we present 17 ancient plague genomes from Eurasia dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP. This increased dataset enabled us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can increase SOC storage in grassland-derived Mollisols remain uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and applying manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. However, these practices did not increase SOC storage in perennial pastures. These results highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial grasslands into agricultural systems to increase SOC storage in the long term. Our findings also highlight the importance of soil health management practices that increase microbial biomass and diversity in annual cropping systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses into humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource will be of interest to a broad audience of scientists, policy makers, and the general public.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators. In this study, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this compound in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. We demonstrate that nesocodin is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator, Phelsuma geckos. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of red nectar. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions. However, the population history of Europe during the period between the migrations and the fall of the Roman Empire is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had skull deformations that were surgically corrected in the 6th century AD. Our results indicate that these women had a genetic ancestry that is not typical for northern and central Europeans. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid, accurate, and scalable diagnostics in resource-scarce settings. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a powerful tool that can identify a broad range of pathogens in a single test. Here, we describe the use of mNGS to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid public health response. Ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a blueprint for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous manner, with the lagging strand synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The lagging strand template is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a complex with the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the observed kinetic behavior of pol δ in human cells. They also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme may be a key factor in the evolution of the human genome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the ability to synthesize all of the components of life, including nucleic acids, in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is still a big challenge. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is a promising treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential metal for all organisms, but it is also a highly toxic metal that must be tightly regulated. In fungi, the role of copper in cellular metabolism is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products has not been demonstrated. Here we report the discovery of xanthocillin, a family of isocyanide metabolites derived from the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) of Aspergillus fumigatus. The xan BGC is present in several filamentous fungi, and the existence of the xan BGC in eukaryotic organisms suggests a role for this BGC in the regulation of copper homeostasis. Xanthocillin has significant antimicrobial properties, and copper-dependent antimicrobial properties were demonstrated for xanthocillin-treated Pseudomonas aeruginosa. These results suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. This article is protected by copyright. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a rare mineral in the Martian sedimentary record. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism in the crater region. The amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica and/or precipitated salts and oxides and is possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of tridymite and other minerals in the sedimentary rock suggests that the sediment source region was in the crater region. Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a major cause of economic losses in agriculture and forestry. The geographic distribution of frost events is changing due to climate warming. We use a large dataset of leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance traits to infer the evolutionary strategies of woody plants for minimizing frost damage. We then use this information to forecast the future vulnerability of forests to frost damage. Our results show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing, and that the future frost risk will increase in some regions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can induce colitis by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and can also support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms underlying the development of Th17 cells may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different mutations causing the same disease. The disease is also sporadic, with no known cause. The disease is progressive, with motor neurons dying over time. There is no cure for the disease. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can slow or stop the disease. This will lead to the development of new treatments for ALS. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which microbes influence vector fitness are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma to vertebrate hosts. We demonstrate that IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall polymer, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how infectious agents influence vector fitness and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early evolution of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). This new taxon, named Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of the components of the climate system. In this paper, we show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of pigments that absorb light in the visible spectrum. In others, the color is determined by the presence of pigments that absorb light in the near-infrared spectrum. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be modulated by the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that absorbs light in the near-infrared spectrum. This discovery provides a molecular explanation for the evolution of blue-green coloration in vertebrates. It also provides a mechanism for modulating the color of animals, which can be useful for camouflage. Finally, it provides a new target for the development of therapeutics for the treatment of liver diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, a demethylase that demethylates m6A in the NANOG mRNA. We show that ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in breast cancer cells, and that ALKBH5 expression is required for the induction of the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype by hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in cancer cells may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides.
