The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. Understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depends on an accurate and precise age model. U-Pb zircon dates for five volcanic ash beds from the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China, define an age model for the extinction and allow exploration of the links between global environmental perturbation, carbon cycle disruption, mass extinction, and recovery at millennial timescales. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for neutralizing antibodies. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in complex with the human receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, at 3.1-Å resolution. The structure of the complex provides insight into the receptor binding site and the conformational changes that occur in the spike protein as it binds to the cell membrane. The structure will be useful for the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. In this paper, we study the evolution of these properties under pressure. We find that under pressure, atoms become pseudo–noble-gas, meaning that they have a closed d-shell configuration. Furthermore, we find that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become electron acceptors, while the elements right after them become highly electropositive. These results are of fundamental importance in chemistry and can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and its effects on climate. We find that human demography tends to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, this effect is uncertain and depends on socioeconomic trajectory and emissions scenario. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand and manage fire in a changing climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic delivery of a single glycan. We show that the glycan is released by the host only at dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most stable. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which use the resulting carbon and energy to maintain a stable symbiont population. This glycan is also required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbionts. We propose that this strategy is used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding human behavior. However, the latent structure of text data is often unknown. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful for understanding human behavior.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for more than four centuries. The disease was spread by rodents, which were introduced into Europe by the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of the rodent reservoirs. We also show that the climate conditions in Europe were favorable for the introduction of the disease into the harbors of Europe. Our results suggest that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of the rodent reservoirs, while the climate conditions in Europe were favorable for the introduction of the disease into the harbors of Europe. This suggests that the disease was not introduced by a single event, but rather by multiple introductions, which were separated by periods of climate stability. This is consistent with the hypothesis that the disease was spread by rodents, which were introduced into Europe by the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of wasting disease. The disease is characterized by behavioral changes, lesions, loss of turgor, limb autotomy, and death. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. The virus is transmitted by starfish and is associated with the disease. The virus is likely to be spread by starfish feeding on infected prey.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the prognosis of AML patients is poor, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor, which is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells, have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data. We find that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several waves, with a recent demographic growth. In addition, we find that the settlement of Madagascar was sex biased, with a higher contribution of males from Southeast Asia. Finally, we find that the present genomic structure of Madagascar is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several independent waves. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, and their knowledge is critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often difficult to access and use. We propose a method to convert the subjective crop rating data provided by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting index is robust across different crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of harnessing the power of people as sensors to improve agricultural decision-making. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor other agricultural variables such as soil moisture, plant diseases, and pests.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neural circuits. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a biologically plausible mechanism that does not rely on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity for storage. It is also sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because of the difficulty in obtaining a clear picture of the environmental conditions that prevailed during this transition. Here, we study the molecular evolution of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy. We show that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is linked to the loss of photosynthesis and the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals has revolutionized condensed matter physics. The first quasicrystals were discovered in the 1980s, but the conditions under which they form are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals and the history of nuclear weapons.

(Bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in photosynthesis, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. A diiron enzyme from the purple betaproteobacterium Rubrivivax (Rvi.) gelatinosus rescues the loss of its cyanobacterial ortholog, cycI, in Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803, whereas coexpression of cyanobacterial cycI and ycf54 is required to complement the loss of acsF in Rvi. gelatinosus. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings also suggest that ASK1 may be a phase-specific mediator of glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycInfo Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. Thus, anthropogenic warming is increasing the likelihood of the most extreme droughts in California. This conclusion is consistent with the findings of other studies.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder of unknown cause. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein STIM1 and in ORAI1, the gene product of which is mutated in myopathy, are associated with a syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and miosis. We show that the mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 result in gain-of-function of the CRAC channel, and that these mutations are associated with thrombocytopenia and spontaneous bleeding in zebrafish embryos. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation and aggregation of misfolded proteins. These aggregates are thought to be the cause of the disease, but the mechanisms by which they spread throughout the brain are not well understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading and pathology in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the role of aggregates in spreading and disease progression in other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. By selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection, MTX inhibited the antiviral responses of the host and facilitated viral infection. MTX had no effect on the aminopeptidase function of LTA4H and therefore did not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is a promising target for cancer therapy, but its clinical development has been hampered by the lack of small-molecule inhibitors. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We also report a cell-line screen that reveals that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines. Finally, we report a mechanism of SHMT inhibition that is particularly effective in DLBCL, a cancer type that is particularly difficult to treat. Collectively, these results provide a platform for the development of SHMT inhibitors for cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are composed of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. Thus, the presence of metastable proteins in inclusions may be a general feature of neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that this work will inspire future experiments and inspire the development of new photonic crystal devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The earliest flowering plants are poorly known, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is still a matter of debate. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, provides new insights into the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology. In this study, we present the first ancient viral sequences of human parvovirus B19 (B19V). We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising, and it is rising because of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is important for understanding the impacts of sea level rise and for assessing the validity of climate models. The study also provides a new estimate of the rate of climate change, which is important for understanding the causes of sea level rise.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the causes of the increase in pain are not well understood. We show that pain is higher today for all adults than it was for today’s elderly. This increase is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of a key enzyme intermediate. The study is of broad interest to the enzymology community, as it highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. The study also highlights the importance of the integration of NMR and X-ray crystallography in enzymology, as the two techniques are complementary and can be used together to provide a more complete picture of enzyme mechanisms. Finally, the study provides a detailed example of how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to study the dynamics of a chemical reaction. These are all important contributions to the field. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication that has shown efficacy in vitro against MERS and SARS coronaviruses. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir prevented and treated MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model, and reduced the severity of disease. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to patients and the global community. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic delivery of a single glycan. We show that the glycan is released by the host only at dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most stable. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which use the resulting carbon and energy to maintain a stable symbiont population. This glycan is also required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbionts. We propose that this strategy is used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved by encouraging teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention halved suspension rates and bolstered the respect of previously suspended students for their teachers. These findings have implications for the design of scalable interventions to reduce suspension rates.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. We found that the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three alkylated DNA lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a major cause of disease. Changing the diets of the population is a key strategy for reducing these impacts. However, the food environment in which people make decisions is complex and can be difficult to change. Here, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% led to a 40% increase in vegetarian meal sales. This is equivalent to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61% and is a large effect in the context of a complex food environment. These results suggest that simple changes to the physical environment in which people make decisions can have a large impact on population health and the environment. They also suggest that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets at the population level. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in catering outlets in the food system. Such an increase would have a large impact on population health and the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. Addition of a potent MEK inhibitor that blocks MAPK signaling brings each oncogene-induced surfaceome back to a common state reflecting the strong dependence of the oncogene on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof

In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has a large number of mutations, but the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is formed by a disulfide-linked dimer, which is not possible for SARS-CoV. The structure also reveals a noncovalent dimerization interface that is also unique to SARS-CoV-2. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body. In this study, we found that hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats. We also found that hypoxic hypoxia triggers the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the brain, which acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also provide a potential mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in the brain of patients with COVID-19. (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/33999999)

The world is full of associations. We are interested in finding the strongest ones. But we must be careful not to mistake a strong association for a causal one. We describe a method for assessing the strength of associations that is appropriate for the era of big data.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2 is a transcription factor that is important for both endothelial and hematopoietic development. In this study, we show that ETV2 can induce the formation of ETVECs, which can improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model. Our study provides a promising approach for the generation of ETVECs, which can be used for the development of vascular networks in the treatment of ischemic disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 for the generation of ETVECs provides a new strategy for the study of human EC development. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research. In this study, we show that zebrafish, a model system for studying human diseases, can be used to study the function of these ligands. We demonstrate that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands display a severe impairment in iridophore patterning. This phenotype is mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system for studying the function of augmentor ligands and their role in human diseases. It also provides a new tool for studying the function of Ltk in vivo. Finally, it provides a model system for studying the function of orphan RTKs in vivo.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the molecular basis of the disease is still unknown. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired β-cell function, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are composed of eight RNA segments, which are packaged into viral particles. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses and might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. Recent studies have demonstrated significant roles of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, increasing the risk of wildfire to people and property. This paper provides a quantitative assessment of the role of humans in increasing the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. We find that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the virus in the host has been the focus of intense study. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the rate of viral production, the time between cell infection and viral production, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus. We also estimate the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. We assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. We predict that favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. This treatment can be given 2 d postinfection, whereas treatment given at the time of infection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of stressors, including global warming and ocean acidification. In addition, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis due to heat stress is a major threat to coral reefs worldwide. Here, we show that the metabolic and physiological changes that precede the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are driven by altered nutrient cycling. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn promotes the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide insights into the processes that lead to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help us to understand the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. This may ultimately help us to conserve these valuable ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a major barrier between the host and the external environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may have implications for the treatment of cancer and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may have implications for the treatment of cancer and the microbiome. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is linked to a unique, ∼192-y series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica. These changes are hypothesized to have led to a change in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which in turn triggered the deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can trigger climate changes that are linked to the start of deglaciation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of biodiversity and ecosystem services. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries and use it to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Show more)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely refractory to regeneration. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway mediating regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the sensory dendrite and is enhanced by reducing neuronal activity and elevating cAMP. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for discovery of factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, this form of regeneration may be a useful model for studying the control of regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of DNA replication. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and for the generation of genetic variation in the offspring of sexually reproducing organisms. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions exhibiting no detectable recombination. We also find that recombination rates tend to peak near the start of genes and fall off sharply, exhibiting polarity. These results are similar to those observed in yeast and in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each with its own characteristic pattern of activity. This hypothesis has been validated in a variety of experimental paradigms. However, the RSN hypothesis has been difficult to test in clinical populations because of the lack of a reliable method to identify and validate RSNs. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN), whereas the subordinate RSN was topographically similar to the task-negative network (TRN). Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the DMN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, whereas the TRN was activated. In contrast, in advanced Parkinson’s disease, the DMN was activated. These results provide a method to identify and validate RSNs in clinical populations. They also provide a method to assess the functional significance of RSNs in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the most studied modification is the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. In this study, we show that this modification also occurs on nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNAs (mRNAs) in yeast. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is not found on all NAD+ containing mRNAs. This suggests that the 5′ NAD+ cap may have a role in modulating the function of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of people with diabetes. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA-me alterations at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes of people with diabetes are associated with glycemia for several years during the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder, which is characterized by a high prevalence of psychiatric symptoms. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. © 2015, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world. They are a major source of many important nutrients, and their flavor is a major factor in their acceptance. The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the composition of the volatile organic compounds present in the fruit. These compounds are synthesized in the fruit, and the composition of the volatile profile is largely determined by the biosynthetic pathways of the volatile precursors. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the biosynthesis of a large number of the volatile organic compounds in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase, which catalyzes the sequential hydroxylation of a single nitrogen atom in the precursor molecule. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also provides a model for the study of the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatile compounds in plants. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We find that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, indicating that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we find a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the local map of space, which is composed of grid cells, head-direction cells, border cells, and object-vector cells. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of the space-encoding circuitry in MEC. They also suggest that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. This organization may facilitate the formation of the local map of space. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system. The dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) project to the striatum, where they control movement. The dopamine system also includes other neurons in the midbrain, including those in the striosomes, which are thought to be involved in the control of motivation and mood. Here, we show that striosomes project to the striatum and that the striosomes are connected to the SNc, which is the major source of dopamine in the striatum. We also show that striosomes are connected to the SNc via a specialized system of neurons and processes. This system, which we call “striosome–dendron bouquets,” is likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We have long sought to understand how we know when two people are connected. In this work, we show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected they feel. This effect is driven by the speed with which people respond to their partners, not by the speed at which they respond to others. This effect is used by third-party listeners to predict how connected two people are. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are characterized by the presence of specialized Ca2+ release machinery, which allows them to generate action potentials. In this study, we show that the Ca2+ release machinery is also responsible for the generation of action potentials. We show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SAN cells and is required for the generation of action potentials. These findings reveal a previously unknown role for the Ca2+ release machinery in the generation of action potentials. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivory have not been well studied. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonate biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses by Si and the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the same signaling pathway to mediate insect resistance in plants. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of other lipids, including glycosylated ceramides and cardiolipins. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. These findings may help to understand the role of ether lipids in the regulation of macrophage function. They may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases associated with ether lipid metabolism.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neural populations. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to integrate information over time. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the successful delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution is a major cause of degraded aquatic ecosystems. In the United States, most of the nutrients that enter lakes and rivers come from small tributaries. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused almost exclusively on large rivers and lakes. This study reveals that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to large water bodies. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare configurations of the mechanical degrees of freedom. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of complex systems that are biased toward rare configurations.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change intrinsic cortical connections and neuronal population dynamics to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. Based on local field potential recordings in a mouse model, we validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry. Using this model, we identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we use the mouse model to show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same mechanisms that cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in NMDAR-Ab encephalitis may also be responsible for seizures in other autoimmune encephalitis. The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid climate change, and it is important to understand the history of abrupt climate change in the past. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred ∼304 Ma, during a glacial period. We show that this event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. The event is important for understanding the history of abrupt climate change and the potential for future abrupt climate change. It also provides insights into the potential for the release of organic matter–derived carbon to the deep ocean and the potential for anoxia of the deep ocean. This article is protected by copyright. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s leading producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for reducing deforestation and fire in tropical landscapes. Rather, it is a tool that can be used in combination with other strategies to reduce deforestation. We hope that our findings will help inform the development of other certification schemes and policies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex is determined by a polygenic process. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that polygenic sex determination produces modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Understanding the evolution of sex determination is critical for understanding the evolution of sex differences in vertebrates. (Show more)

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings indicate that Fe is a key factor in the degradation of bisretinoids. Thus, Fe chelation may be a useful strategy to protect the retina from the damaging effects of bisretinoids. Predator specialization is a key process in the evolution of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The hominin hand is a complex structure that has been the focus of intense study for more than a century. Despite the wealth of information available from the fossil record, fundamental questions remain about the evolution of the human hand. Here we report the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand and suggests that the complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is a promising target for cancer therapy, but its clinical development has been hampered by the lack of small-molecule inhibitors. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We also report a cell-line screen that reveals that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines. Finally, we report a mechanism of SHMT inhibition that is unique to lymphoma cell lines. These findings provide a platform for the development of SHMT inhibitors for cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is facing a triple crisis of hunger, malnutrition, and environmental degradation. Agricultural intensification is a key strategy to address these challenges, but little consideration is given to the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. In this study, we show that deforestation can reduce people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy, and that forest fragmentation can increase people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Our results suggest that strategies to improve nutrition should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting these goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to test the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. This approach can be used to test the impact of other environmental interventions on people’s diets.

Modern agriculture is the most productive and efficient food production system in history. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest dinosaurs, the sauropods, had a much higher prevalence of fixed foraging trails than other groups of dinosaurs. Our findings have important implications for the study of the evolution of animal behavior and the role of ecological factors in the development of modern agricultural practices. They also suggest that the effects of mechanization on soil ecology may have been similar to those of the dinosaurs. This hypothesis needs to be tested in future research. (Show more)
